history.content:
I think what will impress companies the most is having a full-featured, well-thought out personal project completed. Could be a mobile app, web server, ML pipeline, etc. Just make sure it is well documented on your GitHub. This will show companies that you made the most of the time home during quarantine and that you have personal drive to build something from scratch. Save the LeetCode/HackerRank for later (to brush up on common interview questions). Make sure you know the project inside and out so you can impress companies with your work and attention to detail.

As an added bonus, being able to think thru all the subproblems from a full featured project will certainly supplement your coding knowhow, making LC/HR style questions much easier to think through and break down. Of course, this is the opinion of an undergrad who just graduated. But I personally think that UCB EECS recruiting culture focuses way too much on how important it is to master interview questions. Completing a personal project is far more rewarding and impressive to the companies that actually know how to look for talent.

As a starting point, think of something that you want to build that might make your life or the lives of people around you easier. It doesn't have to be an original idea (could be a navigation app, social media clone, todo app, fitness tracker, etc. to name a few examples) but make sure it acts as a solution for something you care about. Then, pick the ideal medium for the project (e.g. mobile, web, CLI) and then research some interesting technologies that are prevalent in industry (e.g. React is widely used for front end, GraphQL is becoming a go-to data fetching protocol, PyTorch is a great way to implemented scalable ML models, etc.) and then apply these technologies to your problem.

children.subject: Since you are still in college, putting any technical experience is always great to indicate that you have worked in a professional engineering environment before. Of course, as you gain more relevant experience you can start cutting less relevant expertise. But since you’re want to pivot from hardware to software, try emphasizing your side projects over professional experience. I did the same thing when I only had a summer of electrical engineering research when I wanted to do software.

Thank you for the detailed response! As a followup, would the student answer (or someone else) recommend that I include the internship experience mentioned in the original post on my resume if I'm getting into a different industry?

history.content:
Hey everyone! Sorry for the long post! I need some advice/tips for breaking into software engineering. I'm currently heading into my senior year and really have had only one internship experience in an EE related industry I don't intend on getting into in the future. I accepted that role with the idea that I just needed to get "something" that summer, which was probably the wrong mindset. As far as this current summer, COVID has somewhat limited my opportunities, only managing to secure a couple of interviews but not getting any further than that. So, I've been taking summer courses in the meantime. However, I would really like to increase my competitiveness as a student/applicant for the upcoming recruiting season (and throughout the year) so I have a chance at snagging a software engineering related opportunity upon graduation, or maybe even the spring semester, if that's realistic. For some background, I did not have programming experience before attending Berkeley and I don't have any personal project experience due to having to devote a lot of my time to my coursework, and other personal issues. I've taken courses such as CS170, CS186, and planning to take CS169, CS162, and CS168 (among other EECS courses like 126 and 151) in my final semesters. However, this summer, I've been trying to increase my skillset by learning web and iOS development. So, I guess my question is, what would be pertinent tasks to prepare for the upcoming rounds of recruiting? Reviewing 61B and 170 material? Practicing coding challenges on LeetCode and HackerRank? Working on a personal project? (Insert advice here)? 

Thank you and, again, apologies for the rambling post!
history.subject: Advice for Upcoming Senior
